articles.headline: Pumping Hydrogen
articles.snippet: On Santa Monica Boulevard in Los Angeles, a futuristic experiment posing as an ordinary fuel station may be bringing the world one step closer to the hydrogen age.
articles.abstract: On Santa Monica Boulevard in Los Angeles, a futuristic experiment posing as an ordinary fuel station may be bringing the world one step closer to the hydrogen age.
articles.lead_paragraph: ON a strip of Santa Monica Boulevard in Los Angeles, a futuristic experiment posing as an ordinary fuel station may be bringing the world one step closer to the hydrogen age.

articles.headline: Coal, a Tough Habit to Kick
articles.snippet: Cleaner sources of fuel remain more expensive, less available and in shorter supply than an old standby.
articles.abstract: Cleaner sources of fuel remain more expensive, less available and in shorter supply than an old standby.

articles.headline: Buffett Deal at Goldman Seen as a Sign of Confidence
articles.snippet: Warren E. Buffett’s announcement that his Berkshire Hathaway would buy $5 billion in preferred shares of Goldman Sachs heartened investors.
articles.abstract: Warren E. Buffett’s announcement that his Berkshire Hathaway would buy $5 billion in preferred shares of Goldman Sachs heartened investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Warren E. Buffett, the country’s most famous investor and one of the world’s richest men, announced on Tuesday that he would invest $5 billion in Goldman Sachs, the embattled Wall Street titan, in a move that could bolster confidence in the financial markets.

articles.headline: Wall Street Workers Find New Niches, or Move On
articles.snippet: As the turmoil in the markets spreads, it is as much a pandemic of the everyman as it is of the Hamptons set.
articles.abstract: As the turmoil in the markets spreads, it is as much a pandemic of the everyman as it is of the Hamptons set.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not everybody on Wall Street is a millionaire, and as the turmoil in the markets spreads, it is as much a pandemic of the everyman as it is of the Hamptons set.

articles.headline: Fast Food Hits Mediterranean; a Diet Succumbs
articles.snippet: Associated with lower rates of heart disease and cancer, the Mediterranean diet is in retreat in its home region.
articles.abstract: Associated with lower rates of heart disease and cancer, the Mediterranean diet is in retreat in its home region.
articles.lead_paragraph: KASTELI, Greece  Dr. Michalis Stagourakis has seen a transformation of his pediatric practice here over the past three years. The usual sniffles and stomachaches of childhood are now interspersed with far more serious conditions: diabetes, high blood pressure, high cholesterol. A changing diet, he says, has produced an epidemic of obesity and related maladies.

articles.headline: Congress Objects to Lack of Help Aimed at Homeowners
articles.snippet: Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. warned that if Congress failed to pass the $700 billion plan, it risked causing a recession and increasing joblessness.
articles.abstract: Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. warned that if Congress failed to pass the $700 billion plan, it risked causing a recession and increasing joblessness.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The White House waged a multifront campaign Tuesday to persuade Congress to accept its vast economic bailout plan, though many in Congress, still unhappy with what they were hearing, continued to push for changes that would provide stronger protection for taxpayers and impose tougher terms on financial institutions.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: F.B.I. Looks Into 4 Firms at Center of the Economic Turmoil
articles.snippet: The F.B.I. opened preliminary investigations into possible fraud involving Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, Lehman Brothers and the American International Group.
articles.abstract: The F.B.I. opened preliminary investigations into possible fraud involving Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, Lehman Brothers and the American International Group.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Federal Bureau of Investigation, under pressure to look at possible criminal activity in the financial markets, is expanding its corporate fraud inquiries in the wake of the tumult in the last 10 days, officials said Tuesday.

articles.headline: In Bailout Furor, Wall Street Pay Becomes a Target
articles.snippet: The stratospheric pay packages of Wall Street executives have become a lightning rod issue.
articles.abstract: The stratospheric pay packages of Wall Street executives have become a lightning rod issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: Congress wants Wall Street to feel it where it hurts: the wallet.

articles.headline: McCain Aide’s Firm Was Paid by Freddie Mac
articles.snippet: The disclosure undercuts a remark by Senator John McCain that his campaign manager, Rick Davis, had no involvement with the company for the last several years.
articles.abstract: The disclosure undercuts a remark by Senator John McCain that his campaign manager, Rick Davis, had no involvement with the company for the last several years.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  One of the giant mortgage companies at the heart of the credit crisis paid $15,000 a month from the end of 2005 through last month to a firm owned by Senator John McCain’s campaign manager, according to two people with direct knowledge of the arrangement.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Pinpoint Attacks Focus on Obama
articles.snippet: A series of ads in Michigan highlights this year’s roughest political attacks: narrowly aimed shots from small groups.
articles.abstract: A series of ads in Michigan highlights this year’s roughest political attacks: narrowly aimed shots from small groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: STERLING HEIGHTS, Mich. — Hundreds of times in the past three weeks, cable television viewers here have been the exclusive audience for two of the roughest advertisements of the political season.

articles.headline: Solar Panels Are Vanishing, Only to Reappear on the Internet
articles.snippet: Solar power, with its promise of emissions-free renewable energy, boasts a growing number of fans. Some of them, it turns out, are thieves.
articles.abstract: Solar power, with its promise of emissions-free renewable energy, boasts a growing number of fans. Some of them, it turns out, are thieves.
articles.lead_paragraph: DESERT HOT SPRINGS, Calif.  Solar power, with its promise of emissions-free renewable energy, boasts a growing number of fans. Some of them, it turns out, are thieves.

articles.headline: Issue Is Payback, Not Bailout
articles.snippet: There are two questions that matter most: What steps are most likely to solve the immediate crisis? And how can the long-term cost to taxpayers be minimized?
articles.abstract: There are two questions that matter most: What steps are most likely to solve the immediate crisis? And how can the long-term cost to taxpayers be minimized?

articles.headline: Stress Rises in Markets for Credit; Yields Fall
articles.snippet: A new bout of anxiety gripped the credit markets on Wednesday as banks hoarded cash and investors once again rushed for the safest of investments, like Treasury bills.
articles.abstract: A new bout of anxiety gripped the credit markets on Wednesday as banks hoarded cash and investors once again rushed for the safest of investments, like Treasury bills.
articles.lead_paragraph: A new bout of anxiety gripped the credit markets on Wednesday as banks hoarded cash and investors once again rushed for the safest of investments, like Treasury bills.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: North Koreans Bar Inspectors at Nuclear Site
articles.snippet: The move left the country on the verge of restarting a nuclear weapons program whose shutdown was portrayed as a significant diplomatic achievement.
articles.abstract: The move left the country on the verge of restarting a nuclear weapons program whose shutdown was portrayed as a significant diplomatic achievement.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  North Korea’s move to resume the reprocessing of plutonium, perhaps as soon as next week, left the country on the verge of restarting a nuclear weapons program whose shutdown had been portrayed by the White House as a significant diplomatic achievement.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Elaine Sciolino
